data.output: The skill of written communication is dying. Having worked away from home for extended periods of time from loved ones, I would eagerly anticipate the arrival of a letter to pick up my morale. Now we write emails sent electronically, but I used to love a trip to the post box to send my communication instead. Email is easier and prevents the need to purchase a rather expensive stamp to deliver them these days. Electronic emails are instantly sent and received rather than have to specifically take a trip out to send a letter by post.

When I used to work at the old newspaper printing press factory, we used to have to manually insert the letter stamp tiles into the device to print the text onto the newspapers. This was a very time-consuming process, however once the job was completed, I felt a sense of pride that we managed to get the newspapers ready on time. Once they were bundled up, we would have to pack them onto shipping pallets ready to send to the stores to sell.

I could hear the stamp of the soldiers' boots as they marched past my cottage. Their uniforms neat and precise, each young man appearing much as the last. I wondered to myself what differences lay under the outer layers which gave them such a singular appearance. Perhaps one wore lady's underwear! I chuckled to myself. Perhaps there was a lover's letter tucked inside a pocket, penned in secret and hidden away until a chance to send it.

Today I sold one of my skylanders. I went to tescos to send it to the buyer. they have an evri machine which prints out the label/stamp. It was so easy. I did it with a box, not sure if you can do it with a letter.

The letter sat amongst others on the mat at the empty house, i was about to show to the clients.     The musty smell around the house was tickling my nose and i could see spiders.  Should I stamp on them or pick them up with one of the letters and send them on their way in the garden.

Josie was a quiet girl who lived in a small village and had a hobby as a stamp collector. Her dad worked in the local post office so she had access to lots of stamps and loved seeing all the different types on the letters that came though the post office, although she would never use any of her stamp collection on normal letters herself, they were too special to her. When letters would be returned to the post office when a letter couldn't be posted, her father would send the old stamps her way.
It was 2040 and Marly was sat at the breakfast table with her robot. "Many years ago, we could only send a letter if we had a stamp. Nobody uses stamps any more."

The newest member of the stamp club blitzed through the school corridor in an attempt to make a punctual start to his time at the club. In the event of this rush, he dropped his most valuable stamp as it slipped out of his book beyond the boy's knowledge. 2 hours later, he made his way back to same route he took, only to find that somebody else had already used his stamp to send off a letter.

"Send for the detective" screamed the woman staring at the body on the ground. Detective Monroe soon arrived and could clearly see the body had been long dead, the letter of the infamous stamp killer, stamped onto the victims head with significant force was plain to see. Thirteen months and thirteen deaths, each one with a letter on their head, following the alphabet. Monroe only hoped they could stop the killer before they got to Z, or he would go postal.

"Just send it bro!" Jesse's friends were shouting to him at the bottom of the waterfall; as they continued to stamp their feet, he looked at the sign that exclaimed just metres from him, "No diving!" As a lad who never clung to the letter of the law he jumped; only noticing the green of the algae shining on the rocks below as he reached them.

"Thanks for listening and please send your friends to the show!" Ellis said to the audience. Ellis had just completed her first one-woman show of her tour, and the show was called 'A letter to my younger self'. She was so proud of herself, she hadn't let production interfere too much and her personal stamp remained well and truly on the show.

There are some letters that I have always wanted to send, but I never have. Whether that's because I don't quite have the words, or I have the words but not the recipient. One time, it was because I didn't have a stamp, and then the letter got so destroyed just sitting in my bag that I thought fate was telling me to give up. Maybe today is the day.

"Stamp your name up in the stars!" Was it an old song a friend of mine used to sing? I tried to remember his name, but it was gone in the mist of time. My memory was getting worse, then I remembered the last letter he sent me. Did I send a reply?

They had a love for beauty, of things done and action taken. The stamp was a special one, an anniversary stamp for a major national event. Eventually they'd send the letter, but in this case it was about appreciating the event and process. It was a lovely gesture for someone they cared deeply about.
I was angry. A great stamp of the feet. The first letter of my name had come out wrong on my new monogram logo. I'll have to send it back.

Whilst marking my pupil's test scores, I use a different colour stamp based on their performance. If they have done well, the stamp is green. If they have done poorly, the stamp is red and I send the student to an after school revision class. To get permission for this, I must get a permission letter signed by their parents.

I open the letter in anticipation,  would it be good or bad news.  I read and re-read the words slowly.  We've done it!!  I stamp my feet in approval.  Excited, I send message to my husband, telling him the good news.

Stamp prices are really expensive. There was a letter that was received by someone and they were interested in how much it cost the sender to send it. They researched how much the specific stamp used cost the sender and they were shocked at the price. They remember when stamps used to be really cheap. It made them realise one of the reasons why less letters are sent by post.

My mother said she never gets any post anymore, that everything is by email or phone call!! So I decided to give her a surprise and write her a little letter.  I could send it on the way home from work and she would get it hopefully in a few days.  I got out my notecards and sent a little hello from me and quickly put it in the envelope.  Oh no, I needed a stamp!!

yesterday i received a letter in the post . As i pulled it out of the letterbox I jumped back. A large spider had come in with it. In order to avoid it running up my leg I was hopping about and also trying not to stamp on it. In the end I opened the door and it moved to the step. I used the sweeping brush to help send it on its way.

A man was looking for a stamp to emboss onto a letter he had to send before the end of the day. He went to the supermarket to find a suitable stamp with some ink to apply it with. On his return trip he realised he lived only 200 yards from a post box which would allow him to send it today.

Today I wrote a heartfelt letter to my best friend, telling her all about the things I had gone through as of late. I sealed it up and hurried to the post office, excited to send it as this was my first letter I had written and I wanted to start exchanging letters as it felt so novel! But in a rush, I forgot to put a stamp on the envelope. Weeks went by, and my friend never got the letter. I wondered where it had gone, everyday asking her if she had received anything nice lately not wanting to ruin the surprise but a feeling of melancholy if this may have been a sign not to do this.

As I was preparing to send my gifts out, I walked up to the door of the post office and noticed a letter lying on the ground. It had the most beautiful stamp design on the corner, I'd never seen anything like it. I then looked closer and with sudden shock realized it was addressed to me. I took a sharp breath in and looked around to see if there was anyone i knew nearby, I was the only person there, so I quickly popped it into my bag, to open it as soon as I got home.
I asked my friend about sending the letter as I was new in the country. He told me how to stamp the letter and and how can I send it by the post. I finally had a good understanding about it.

My partner the bedroom window open during the night to let some cold air in, upon doing so a massive spider scurried in through into the bedroom. This would usually send my partner into a panic but this time she grabbed a letter and gathered it up into a glass and threw it outside. Normally she would send me to stamp on it.
